text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

13.1	The International Trade Centre (ITC) is responsible for the business aspects of trade development, as the joint technical cooperation agency of the United Nations and the World Trade Organization (WTO). The mandate derives from the priorities established by the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) on 19 March 1964 and the General Assembly on 12 December 1967 (Assembly resolution 2297 (XXII)). Since 1 January 1968, ITC has operated under the joint auspices of GATT/WTO and the United Nations. In its resolution 1819 (LV) of 9 August 1973, the Economic and Social Council reaffirmed the Centre’s mandate as the focal point for technical assistance and cooperation activities for trade promotion within the United Nations system of assistance for developing countries.

13.2	In the context of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, Member States explicitly recognized trade as a key engine for sustainable and inclusive economic growth and poverty eradication, specifically through target 8.a of the Sustainable Development Goals, to increase Aid for Trade support, and targets 17.10 and 17.11 of the Goals, for an open, rules-based, transparent and fair trading system and a significant increase in exports from developing countries. In the Pact for the Future, Member States reiterated their commitment to a rules-based, non-discriminatory, open, fair, inclusive, equitable and transparent multilateral trading system and emphasized the promotion of export-led growth in developing countries, in line with WTO commitments.

13.3	Against the backdrop of trade tensions and the severe negative impact on trade and development caused by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, the General Assembly, in its resolutions 79/195 and 78/134, reiterated this position for the target beneficiaries of ITC – micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises – which make up over 90 per cent of the world’s businesses, account for over two thirds of employment and form the economic backbone of every community.
Programme of work
Subprogramme 6 – Operational aspects of trade promotion and export development
Objective

13.4	The objective, to which ITC contributes, is to enhance inclusive and sustainable growth and development through trade and international business development for micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises in developing countries, especially the least developed countries, and countries with economies in transition, through increased business capacities of those enterprises to trade and through a conducive business environment and strengthened institutional ecosystems for those enterprises.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

13.5	To contribute to the objective, ITC will provide advisory services, training and awareness-building to enterprises, business support institutions and government agencies in areas that are key to the international competitiveness of micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises. In particular, ITC will:

(a)	Build enterprise-level capacities in the areas of market analysis, value addition, quality, e-commerce, marketing, access to finance and investment, climate resilience and environmental risk mitigation;

(b)	Provide micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises with market knowledge and new market linkage opportunities, including through initiatives related to digital and sustainable trade and the “Alliances for Action” initiative, which connect businesses to foreign markets and develop public-private partnerships in targeted value chains, strengthening existing and opening new trade channels;

(c)	Enable business transactions and investment for micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises, with a focus on growing local, regional, South-South and global value chains, working with women-owned businesses, youth entrepreneurs, refugees, internally displaced persons and artisan and farmer communities, including through the ITC SheTrades initiative, the Ye! (“young entrepreneurs”) community and the Refugee Empowerment through Markets Initiative;

(d)	Strengthen the governance, performance, advocacy capacities, quality and scope of services of national, subnational and regional business support institutions and ecosystems, including trade and investment promotion agencies, chambers of commerce, sector associations, youth and women’s business groups, cooperatives, incubators and technical and vocational training providers;

(e)	Support policymakers in leading public-private dialogues and consensus-building and decision-making processes that foster the growth and internationalization of micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises, including through the promotion of the benefits of a universal, rules-based, open, predictable, inclusive, non-discriminatory and equitable multilateral trading system under WTO;

(f)	Scale up its comprehensive and globally accessible trade intelligence that addresses information and knowledge gaps, including databases, such as the ITC Sustainability Map and Market Access Map, and the SME Trade Academy digital learning platform;
(g)	In line with the ITC country engagement strategy, strengthen its trade advocacy, partnerships and programmatic planning through an enhanced regional and national presence.
13.6	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Increased resilience of micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises to external shocks and their enhanced competitiveness, sustainable business practices and integration into regional and international value chains that generate business transactions, investments, sustainable jobs and higher incomes, especially for women, youth and persons in vulnerable situations;

(b)	Improved usefulness of services provided by business support institutions to micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises, including enhanced management and operational functioning of the service providers;

(c)	Better-informed government decision makers, with options for new or improved inclusive trade-related policies, strategies and regulatory frameworks that contribute to an enabling environment for micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises to participate in international trade;

(d)	Increased awareness among policymakers, business support organizations and businesses related to trade opportunities and challenges for micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises, market access conditions and sustainable business practices.
13.7	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Extrabudgetary resources will remain stable;
(b)	Political, economic and social conditions in programming countries will remain conducive to development interventions;
(c)	International trade and investment conditions do not deteriorate significantly compared with 2025.

13.8	With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional, national and local levels, ITC will maintain and develop partnerships with the private sector, civil society, academia and trade and development organizations to support market access and provide supplier programmes for micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises in order to advance the 2030 Agenda, the Pact for the Future and the Global Digital Compact annexed thereto. ITC will focus on partnerships that contribute to the ITC Global Small and Medium-sized Enterprises Ministerial Meeting; to the operationalization of key value chains in support of the African Continental Free Trade Area; and to scalable initiatives, especially for the least developed countries, small island developing States and landlocked developing countries. ITC will also focus on partnerships that support key outcomes in areas such as digital trade, investment facilitation, women and trade, and micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises and trade in the run-up to the fourteenth WTO Ministerial Conference, to be held in Cameroon.

13.9	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, ITC will continue to coordinate with United Nations entities, including through membership in the United Nations Sustainable Development Group and United Nations regional and country teams. ITC will collaborate with the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development and WTO, and with other entities and initiatives, such as the World Intellectual Property Organization, the International Telecommunication Union, the International Labour Organization, the International Organization for Migration and the Office of the High Representative for the Least Developed Countries, Landlocked Developing Countries and Small Island Developing States.

13.10	ITC integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. ITC will mainstream gender equality and women’s empowerment throughout its workstreams, including by catalysing reforms of government procurement frameworks to mainstream a gender perspective; changing how business support organizations and financial institutions serve women; strengthening the voice of women’s organizations in the African Continental Free Trade Area; and serving more women in vulnerable situations.

13.11	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, ITC will increase the attention given to disability inclusion in its programming and will implement more initiatives that foster the inclusion of persons with disabilities in trade.
Evaluation activities
13.12	The following evaluations completed in 2024 have guided the proposed programme plan for 2026:
(a)	2024 annual evaluation synthesis report: midterm evaluation of the ITC strategic plan for the period 2022–2025;
(b)	Evaluation of the ITC Ethical Fashion Initiative;
(c)	Midterm evaluation of the project “Linking Ukrainian SMEs in the Fruit and Vegetables Sectors to Global and Domestic Markets and Value Chains – Phase II”;
(d)	Midterm evaluation of the Netherlands Trust Fund Phase V programme;
(e)	Evaluation of the Systematic Mechanism for Safer Trade project.

13.13	In response to the results of the evaluations referenced above, ITC will leverage findings to enhance its impact on Member States’ national development objectives, informing future approaches to maximize impact. For example, ITC will reinforce collaboration with partner institutions to sustain capacity-building for small and medium-sized enterprises. The ITC partnership and capacity-building approaches have also fostered ownership and sustainability and will be replicated by, for example, expanding private sector engagement, enhancing business-to-business matchmaking and strengthening market linkages for micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as by improving its alignment with the resident coordinator system, adapting to donor funding decentralization and deepening its country-level presence, all in line with the ITC country engagement strategy.
13.14	The following evaluations are planned for 2026:
(a)	2026 annual evaluation synthesis report;
(b)	One corporate-level evaluation;
(c)	One evaluation of an ITC thematic area;
(d)	One large project evaluation.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced access to financing for women entrepreneurs in the digital economy

13.15	In developing countries, there are about 8 to 10 million formal small and medium-sized enterprises with at least one female owner. Digital trade is the fastest-growing segment of international trade, with an estimated average annual growth rate of 8 per cent since 2005 and $4.3 trillion in value. Lack of access to financing is one of the key obstacles to the growth of women’s entrepreneurship in international trade. ITC launched the joint WTO-ITC Women Exporters in the Digital Economy Fund in February 2024. Operationalized through the ITC SheTrades initiative, the Fund aims to raise $50 million for thousands of women entrepreneurs in developing and least developed countries. The Fund will provide financing for women entrepreneurs, enabling them to adopt digital technologies and expand the online presence of their enterprises.
13.16	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 13.1).
Table 13.1
Performance measure

table_content.text:
The WTO-ITC Women Exporters in the Digital Economy Fund mobilized over $21 million in pledges, of which $10 million is already available for kick-starting the first phase in four countries targeting at least 400 women-led small and medium-sized enterprises from 2025 onwards 
Over 600 business support organizations responded to a call by the Fund for applications to participate in the programme

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: strengthened digital trade capacity of micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

13.17	The Centre’s work contributed to 11,071 micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises enabled to compete digitally and 30 business support organizations empowered to advocate for connectivity, which exceeded the planned target of 5,000 micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises and 8 business support organizations.
13.18	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 13.I).
Figure 13.I
Performance measure: number of micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises enabled to digitally compete and number of business support organizations empowered to advocate for connectivity (cumulative)

Result 2: strengthened services provided by local business support organizations to small businesses to capitalize on the African Continental Free Trade Area – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

13.19	The Centre’s work contributed to 37 business support organizations that improved their African Continental Free Trade Area-related services and 18,659 small businesses served by business support organizations, which exceeded the planned target of 35 business support organizations and 17,000 micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises.
13.20	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 13.II).
Figure 13.II

Performance measure: number of business support organizations that improved their African Continental Free Trade Area-related services and number of small businesses served by those business support organizations (cumulative)
Result 3: transition of textile and clothing small and medium-sized enterprises in Africa and the Asia-Pacific region to sustainable operations – Proposed programme plan for 2026

13.21	In the textile and clothing industry, the transition towards digitalization and sustainability – in particular its environmental aspects – may increase opportunities for inclusion in global value chains for small and medium-sized enterprises in developing countries. ITC has traditionally worked in textile and clothing value chains in a broad manner, addressing almost all aspects of production and trade to improve competitiveness.
Lessons learned and planned change

13.22	The lesson for ITC was that changing market requirements and industry practices made it necessary to prioritize support for small and medium-sized enterprises in the transition of the textile and clothing industry towards digitalization and sustainability. This will enable small and medium-sized enterprises to meet markets’ increasing demand for more sustainable products in compliance with industry standards and forthcoming regulations. In applying the lesson, ITC will increase its focus on the competitiveness of textile and clothing small and medium-sized enterprises in identified areas and engage with policymakers and business support organizations to provide the framework for textile sustainability and foster a more effective business ecosystem. These changes are expected to enable growth, higher revenues and job creation for textile and clothing small and medium-sized enterprises, while reducing the sector’s impact on the environment.
13.23	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 13.III).
Figure 13.III
Performance measure: number of jobs and sustainability initiatives in textile and clothing small and medium-sized enterprises in Africa and the Asia-Pacific region (cumulative)

Consultation, advice and advocacy: advice to policymakers, trade support institutions and enterprises to address the international competitiveness challenges for micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises in developing countries and countries with economies in transition, to facilitate public-private dialogue on improvements to the business environment and to ensure that trade supports inclusive and sustainable development; advisory services to disadvantaged groups among micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises, such as women- and youth-owned enterprises, on improving their productive capacity and market access; advisory and advocacy services for policymakers and business support institutions on how to consider the needs of micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises and disadvantaged groups in their service offer; and advocacy that allows for the systematic inclusion of such enterprises and disadvantaged groups in policy and strategy processes.

Databases and substantive digital materials: databases and other online tools to make global trade more transparent and facilitate market access and business and policy decisions. Databases cover trade flows, tariffs and non-tariff measures, export potential, procurement opportunities, rules of origin, private standards and knowledge on sustainable trade and youth and women entrepreneurship. They include the SheTrades database for over 48,000 active women entrepreneurs, “SheTrades Outlook”, the ITC “SME Trade Academy”, the Ye! community and platform for over 51,000 young entrepreneurs, the Benchmarking for Trade platform, the Quality for Trade platform reaching 3,700 users, the ecomConnect platform, the suite of regional integrated solutions (African Trade Observatory, West African Competitiveness Observatory, Euromed Trade Helpdesk and Eastern Partnership Trade Helpdesk), which received more than 54,000 visits from over 30,000 users in 2024, and the suite of market analysis tools (Trade Map, Market Access Map, Rules of Origin Facilitator, Export Potential Map, Investment Map, Procurement Map and Global Trade Helpdesk) accessed by more than 2.3 million users, generating over 10.3 million visits in 2024; the Strategies Implementation Management Tool with 57 registered users, the Sustainability Map, with 19,000 active users, the Standards Map, with 89,000 active users, and the ePing platform, with a total of 25,300 registered users.

text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026

children.text: Overview

13.26	ITC carried out a spending review pursuant to paragraph 20 of General Assembly resolution 77/262, as part of its proposed budget exercise for 2026. Under the overall guidance of the Executive Director and with the engagement of all programme managers, a review was carried out for each division of ITC, including an in-depth analysis of the latest post complement and functional profiles, as well as non-post resource types and distribution, with a view to determining the optimal level and types of resources required to implement the mandates of ITC, as set out in the proposed programme plan for 2026.

13.27	The spending review process was implemented in parallel with the development of the ITC strategic plan for the period 2026–2030, which is anchored to the commitment of ITC to fostering inclusive and sustainable economic transformation in developing countries through enhanced competitiveness and trade of small and medium-sized enterprises; this provided an opportunity to align resource allocation with the Centre’s renewed long-term vision. The review pointed to several opportunities for better and more efficient utilization of financial and human resources, including through the reconfiguration of staffing structures, the repurposing of existing posts and the redistribution of non-post resources. The spending review proposals support the realization of the five transformational outcome priorities identified in the strategic plan for the period 2026–2030, namely: (a) the acceleration of trade diversification and value addition; (b) the advancement of the sustainable transition for small and medium-sized enterprises; (c) the enhanced inclusion of small and medium-sized enterprises in the digital economy; (d) the achievement of transformational benefits from trade for small and medium-sized enterprises; and (e) the amplification of the contributions of small and medium-sized enterprises to global advocacy and decision-making. Through the spending review process, ITC aims to reinforce the strategic coherence of its operations and ensure that its resource base is positioned to respond to emerging priorities of Member States and unforeseen challenges over the coming period covered by the strategic plan.

13.28	The outcome of the spending review process highlighted the need for strengthening the trade advocacy, partnerships and programmatic planning of ITC in line with the ITC country engagement strategy, which envisions a more decentralized ITC with a stronger in-country and regional presence to better meet countries’ needs and increase global reach. The ITC country engagement strategy is shaped by several key factors, namely: (a) the need for greater visibility and more direct engagement in country-level discussions; (b) the growing complexity of the ITC project portfolio, requiring stronger coordination at the country level; (c) the increasingly complex needs of countries; (d) the competitive Aid for Trade space, requiring ITC to demonstrate its unique value proposition; and (e) the decentralization of strategic and funding decisions by development partners.

13.29	Furthermore, ITC will launch a new flagship initiative – the Global Small and Medium-sized Enterprises Ministerial Meeting – designed to serve as a high-level platform for strategic dialogue on the development of small and medium-sized enterprises. This initiative will bring together ministers and key global stakeholders to identify and shape policy responses to the most pressing challenges faced by small and medium-sized enterprises, including limited access to finance, uneven digital connectivity and the demands of the sustainable transition. This flagship initiative will also feature a dedicated business and innovation space, aimed at fostering interaction between policymakers and private sector actors, encouraging the exchange of innovative solutions and facilitating investment opportunities in support of the growth of small and medium-sized enterprises. Funding requirements for this initiative are planned to be provided through the reconfiguration of non-post resources in line with the findings of the spending review.
13.30	The proposed regular budget resources for 2026 are reflected in table 13.3.
Table 13.3
Overall United Nations grant to ITC: evolution of financial resources by object of expenditure
(Thousands of United States dollars)
a		Represents the United Nations share of the ITC full regular budget disbursed as a grant.

13.31	ITC operates, from an administrative point of view, on the basis of arrangements agreed upon between the United Nations and GATT/WTO. These arrangements were reviewed in 1998, 1999 and 2004, with the most recent consolidated version (A/79/6 (Sect. 13), annex II) approved in 2024 by the General Assembly in its resolution 79/257 and by the General Council of WTO at its meeting held on 22 and 23 July 2024. The recently approved administrative arrangements consolidate two decades of changes in the budgeting processes of both organizations into a single document, incorporating technical and administrative updates that had not previously been documented in one place; the administrative arrangements also streamline the budget format and review timeline, ensuring alignment between the annual budget cycle of the United Nations and the biennial cycle of WTO. In conformity with the administrative arrangements, the regular budget of ITC is denominated in Swiss francs and is funded equally by the United Nations and WTO. The United Nations share of the ITC full regular budget is disbursed as a grant.

13.32	In accordance with the biennial budget cycle of WTO and the administrative arrangements of ITC, the proposed biennial budget for 2026–2027, which will be submitted for review by WTO bodies, will be set at twice the amount presented in the present document.

13.33	The grant proposed for 2026 amounts to $23,376,800, reflecting no change in the resource level compared with the approved appropriation for 2025. The full regular budget requirements of ITC amount to SwF 38,431,300, net of projected miscellaneous income of SwF 200,000. The United Nations grant remains at 50 per cent of the ITC full regular budget, or SwF 19,215,700. After applying an exchange rate of SwF 0.8220 to $1.00, the United States dollar equivalent is $23,376,800. The proposed level of resources provides for the full, efficient and effective implementation of mandates.

13.34	The total resource requirements for 2026 for ITC, comprising its planned full regular budget in Swiss francs and projected extrabudgetary resources in Swiss francs, are reflected in tables 13.4 and 13.5 and figure 13.IV. For increased clarity and transparency, details of ITC post resources to be provided for by the proposed grants from the United Nations and WTO are presented in tables 13.6 and 13.7 and annex I, notwithstanding that these posts are not part of the proposed or approved staffing table of the United Nations regular budget.

Explanation of variances by factor, component and subprogramme – Overall resource changes
Other changes
13.35	As reflected in tables 13.5 and 13.6, planned resource changes reflect overall cost-neutral changes, as follows:
(a)	Decreased requirements of SwF 25,000 under posts, reflecting:

(i)	The planned redeployment of one D-1 post (formerly intended for the ITC Addis Ababa liaison office) from the Division of Sustainable and Inclusive Trade and one Programme Management Officer (P-3) post from the Division of Country Programmes, both currently located in Geneva, to the ITC regional office in Nairobi, as reflected in annex II (decreased requirements of SwF 25,000). The spending review identified the need for a geographical redeployment of resources in line with the strategic shift of ITC towards enhanced regional presence and proximity to beneficiaries, with the objective of strengthening national- and regional-level engagements, facilitating more responsive technical assistance and enhancing the impact of ITC work in sub-Saharan Africa. The planned redeployment also addresses the recommendation contained in paragraph IV.110 of the first report of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions on the proposed programme budget for 2025 (A/79/7);

(ii)	The planned reclassification of one Chief of Section at the P-5 level in the Division of Country Programmes as Director, Division of Sustainable and Inclusive Trade (D-1); and one Senior Trade Promotion Officer (P-4) as Trade Investment Officer (P-3) in the Division of Market Development, as reflected in annex II (cost-neutral). The spending review recognized the need for leadership at the D-1 level in the Division of Sustainable and Inclusive Trade and identified opportunities for staffing reconfiguration within existing resources while avoiding a top-heavy organizational structure;

(iii)	The planned reassignment of one Programme Management Officer (P-4) as Statistician, one Programme Management Officer (P-3) as Data Analyst and one Driver (General Service (Other level)) as General Services Assistant, as reflected in annex II (cost-neutral). Informed mainly by efforts by ITC to strengthen data management and analysis capacity, the spending review identified the need to reassign three posts for strengthening the capacity required for the customized and data-based analytical support that ITC provides to Member States, including through the global public goods platforms, and the capacity required for the provision of timely, high-quality and effective general administration-related services;
(b)	An increase of SwF 25,000 under non-post resources, as follows:

(i)	Decreased requirements under other staff costs (SwF 55,000), reflecting the anticipated reduction in general temporary assistance needs, mainly through optimization of the staffing arrangements during peak workload periods;

(ii)	Decreased requirements under consultants (SwF 50,000), reflecting the expenditure trend and the anticipated reduction in the need for consultant requirements through small additions to the work assignments of staff members who had worked closely with consultants;

(iii)	Increased requirements under travel of staff (SwF 17,200) to facilitate missions of the staff of the newly established ITC regional office in Nairobi for the provision of technical assistance at the national level, direct stakeholder engagement and representation in key intergovernmental and regional events;

(iv)	Increased requirements under contractual services (SwF 218,700), reflecting the resources required to support the organization of flagship events, including a high-level ministerial meeting, and digitalization efforts of ITC, including the development and enhancement of online normative tools, policy frameworks and digital platforms, such as the global public goods platforms, and their dissemination to a broader range of stakeholders;

(v)	Increased requirements under general operating expenses (SwF 35,000), reflecting increased requirements of SwF 115,000 for operating expenses, including the rental and maintenance of premises for the ITC regional office in Nairobi, which will be located in the United Nations Office at Nairobi complex, offset in part by decreased requirements of SwF 80,000 for postage and pouch services, mainly through the use of digital dissemination methods for publications;
(vi)	Decreased requirements under supplies and materials (SwF 40,000), reflecting the recent expenditure trends and digitalization efforts of ITC;

(vii)	Decreased requirements under grants and contributions (SwF 100,900), reflecting mainly the planned strategic rationalization in the use by ITC of joint administrative services through the optimization of internal processes and redesigned workflows for the more efficient deployment of existing staff capacity.
Extrabudgetary resources

13.36	As reflected in table 13.4 (2), extrabudgetary resources amount to SwF 94,530,000. The extrabudgetary resources would complement regular budget resources and would be used to provide for 20 posts (1 P-5, 3 P-4, 3 P-3, 1 P-2/1 and 9 General Service (Other level) in Geneva and 1 P-3 and 2 General Service (Other level) in the ITC regional office in Nairobi) to perform functions such as human resources management, financial management, monitoring and evaluation, and information and communications technology functions, and similar activities related to the implementation of extrabudgetary projects. In addition, the non-post resources, including project personnel, would be used to implement technical cooperation projects, complementing and leveraging the core expertise and global offering of ITC provided through regular budget resources, at the request of Member States. Extrabudgetary projects will focus on sustainable and resilient value chains, inclusive trade, sustainable trade, digital trade and regional integration, including South-South trade and investment, to illustrate how ITC is transforming trade to drive sustainable development, particularly in an increasingly fragile global landscape. ITC continues to negotiate with donors for the funding of large-scale integrated projects.

13.37	The extrabudgetary resources under the present section are subject to the oversight of ITC, in accordance with the delegation of authority by the Secretary-General, and their use is guided by the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United Nations.
Other information

13.38	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the Centre will continue to integrate environmental management practices into its operations. ITC offsets its carbon footprint, which includes emissions from travel and building operations, by purchasing carbon certificates through the United Nations carbon offset platform. This initiative is aligned with the Climate Neutral Now programme of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change secretariat. ITC calculates its greenhouse gas emissions annually and actively seeks ways to reduce them. However, despite these efforts, there remain residual emissions, and, to achieve climate neutrality, ITC purchases an equivalent amount of carbon credits.

13.39	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 13.8. All ITC personnel receive a monthly newsletter containing compliance rates and the category of non-compliance justifications, as recorded in the enterprise resource planning system, by division, and all managers receive compliance rates on a weekly basis.
Table 13.8

text: Annex I Organizational structure and post distribution for 2026

children.text: Two charts showing the organizational structure of the International Trade Centre (ITC) are presented below. Chart A reproduces the approved organizational structure and post distribution for 2025, as contained in document A/79/6 (Sect. 13), while chart B presents the organizational structure and post distribution for 2026.
Justification for the planned changes

ITC has aligned its structure and delivery requirements to enable the implementation of its strategic plan for the period 2026–2030. The newly created ITC regional office in Nairobi works to advance the Centre’s commitment to fostering inclusive and sustainable economic transformation in developing countries through enhanced competitiveness and trade of small and medium-sized enterprises. The ITC regional office in Nairobi would strengthen the trade advocacy, partnerships and programmatic planning of ITC in line with the ITC country engagement strategy, which envisions a more decentralized ITC with a stronger in-country and regional presence to better meet countries’ needs and increase the global reach of ITC.
A.	Approved organizational structure and post distribution for 2025
B.	Organizational structure and post distribution for 2026

text: Annex II Summary of planned post changes

table_content.text:
Subprogramme 6
Operational aspects of trade promotion and export development
Redeployment of the following posts from Geneva to the ITC regional office in Nairobi:

The planned geographical redeployment of two ITC full regular budget posts from Geneva to Nairobi relates to the establishment of the ITC regional office in Nairobi, which would strengthen the presence of ITC at the national and regional levels and its support to Member States on trade advocacy, partnerships and programmatic planning, in line with the ITC country engagement strategy. The redeployment would enable ITC to provide customized solutions for the trade-related needs of Member States, including for the operationalization of key value chains in support of the African Continental Free Trade Area, through direct interactions at the national and subregional levels. The planned redeployment also addresses the recommendation contained in paragraph IV.110 of the first report of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions on the proposed programme budget for 2025 (A/79/7).

The planned geographical redeployment of two ITC full regular budget posts from Geneva to Nairobi relates to the establishment of the ITC regional office in Nairobi, which would strengthen the presence of ITC at the national and regional levels and its support to Member States on trade advocacy, partnerships and programmatic planning, in line with the ITC country engagement strategy. The redeployment would enable ITC to provide customized solutions for the trade-related needs of Member States, including for the operationalization of key value chains in support of the African Continental Free Trade Area, through direct interactions at the national and subregional levels. The planned redeployment also addresses the recommendation contained in paragraph IV.110 of the first report of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions on the proposed programme budget for 2025 (A/79/7).

The planned geographical redeployment of two ITC full regular budget posts from Geneva to Nairobi relates to the establishment of the ITC regional office in Nairobi, which would strengthen the presence of ITC at the national and regional levels and its support to Member States on trade advocacy, partnerships and programmatic planning, in line with the ITC country engagement strategy. The redeployment would enable ITC to provide customized solutions for the trade-related needs of Member States, including for the operationalization of key value chains in support of the African Continental Free Trade Area, through direct interactions at the national and subregional levels. The planned redeployment also addresses the recommendation contained in paragraph IV.110 of the first report of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions on the proposed programme budget for 2025 (A/79/7).

The planned reassignments relate to efforts by ITC to transform the skill sets, competencies and organizational culture towards a modern, data-driven organization in the context of the Data Strategy of the Secretary-General for Action by Everyone, Everywhere. The planned reassignments would also strengthen the data management and analysis capacity required for the customized analytical support, including through the global public goods platforms, that ITC provides to Member States. The incumbents of the reassigned posts would be responsible for extracting deep insights from large amounts of data through the use of complex models and algorithms.

The planned reassignments relate to efforts by ITC to transform the skill sets, competencies and organizational culture towards a modern, data-driven organization in the context of the Data Strategy of the Secretary-General for Action by Everyone, Everywhere. The planned reassignments would also strengthen the data management and analysis capacity required for the customized analytical support, including through the global public goods platforms, that ITC provides to Member States. The incumbents of the reassigned posts would be responsible for extracting deep insights from large amounts of data through the use of complex models and algorithms.
1 Programme Management Officer as Data Analyst

The planned reassignments relate to efforts by ITC to transform the skill sets, competencies and organizational culture towards a modern, data-driven organization in the context of the Data Strategy of the Secretary-General for Action by Everyone, Everywhere. The planned reassignments would also strengthen the data management and analysis capacity required for the customized analytical support, including through the global public goods platforms, that ITC provides to Member States. The incumbents of the reassigned posts would be responsible for extracting deep insights from large amounts of data through the use of complex models and algorithms.
Reassignment of one Driver as General Services Assistant

The planned reassignment relates to the reduced demand for traditional driver services in Geneva and the increased demand for broader administration-related services. The General Services Assistant would strengthen the capacity for the provision of timely, high-quality and effective general administration-related services and would allow for the more efficient use of the post.
Upward reclassification of one Chief of Section at the P-5 level in the Division of Country Programmes as Director, Division of Sustainable and Inclusive Trade

The planned upward reclassification relates to the findings of the spending review, which recognized the need for leadership at the D-1 level in the Division of Sustainable and Inclusive Trade. Established in 2022, the Division oversees a growing portfolio comprising 12 ITC full regular budget posts and 56 project-funded positions. Therefore, leadership at the D-1 level is essential to effectively respond to the increasing demand for ITC services and to ensure the advancement of critical initiatives focused on environmental sustainability, gender equality, youth empowerment and support for vulnerable communities.
Downward reclassification of one Senior Trade Promotion Officer as Trade Investment Officer in the Division of Market Development

The planned downward reclassification reflects the rejuvenation efforts of ITC. The reclassification would help to prevent the ITC staffing structure from becoming more top-heavy by offsetting the planned upward reclassification (P-5 to D-1) described above.
